review.title: The Influence of Global Constraints on Similarity Measures for Time-Series Databases
review.abstract: A time series consists of a series of values or events obtained over repeated measurements in time. Analysis of time series represents and important tool in many application areas, such as stock market analysis, process and quality control, observation of natural phenomena, medical treatments, etc. A vital component in many types of time-series analysis is the choice of an appropriate distance/similarity measure. Numerous measures have been proposed to date, with the most successful ones based on dynamic programming. Being of quadratic time complexity, however, global constraints are often employed to limit the search space in the matrix during the dynamic programming procedure, in order to speed up computation. Furthermore, it has been reported that such constrained measures can also achieve better accuracy. In this paper, we investigate two representative time-series distance/similarity measures based on dynamic programming, Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) and Longest Common Subsequence (LCS), and the effects of global constraints on them. Through extensive experiments on a large number of time-series data sets, we demonstrate how global constrains can significantly reduce the computation time of DTW and LCS. We also show that, if the constraint parameter is tight enough (less than 10-15% of time-series length), the constrained measure becomes significantly different from its unconstrained counterpart, in the sense of producing qualitatively different 1-nearest neighbor graphs. This observation explains the potential for accuracy gains when using constrained measures, highlighting the need for careful tuning of constraint parameters in order to achieve a good trade-off between speed and accuracy.

metadata.title: The Influence of Global Constraints on Similarity Measures for Time-Series Databases

sections.text: The analysis of time series is an important tool in many application areas, such as stock market analysis, process and quality control, observation of natural phenomena, medical treatments, etc. A critical component in many types of time series analysis is the choice of an appropriate measure of distance / similarity. Numerous measures have been proposed so far, the most successful of which are based on dynamic programming. However, since these measures are square time complexity, global constraints are often applied to limit the search space in the matrix during the dynamic programming process in order to speed up the calculation. Furthermore, it has been reported that such limited measures can also achieve better accuracy. In this paper, we examine two representative time series distance / similarity measures based on dynamic programming, dynamic time warming (DTW) and longest common sub-sequence (LCS) and the effects of global constraints on them. By conducting extensive experiments on a large number of time series data, we can show that global time series constraints such as global time series constraints can be narrowed significantly.

sections.heading: 3. FAP System

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Evaluation
sections.text: In this section, we examine the impact of global constraints on two most illustrative measures of similarity based on dynamic programming: DTW and LCS. In addition, two aspects of the application of global constraints are considered: efficiency and the behavior of the 1NN classifier for different values of constraints. In both constraints, experiments with the unrestricted measurement and a measurement with the following constraints are performed: 75%, 50%, 25%, 20%, 15%, 10%, 5%, 1% and 0% of the size of the time series. This distribution was chosen because actions with larger constraints are expected to behave similar to the unrestricted measurement, while smaller constraints exhibit more interesting behavior [10, 18]. A comprehensive set of experiments was conducted on 38 sets of data from [12], covering the majority of all publicly available data sets in the world designated as time series sets. The length of time series varies from 24 to 1882 depending on the data set.

sections.heading: 4.1. Computational Times
sections.text: In the first phase of the experiment, we wanted to investigate the influence of global constraints LB on the efficiency of the calculation of the distance matrix. However, the distance matrix for a dataset is the matrix in which element (i, j) contains the distance between i-th and j-th time series from the dataset. However, the calculation of the distance matrix is a time-consuming operation, which makes it suitable for measuring the efficiency of global constraints.In Table 1, the calculation times of the DTW in milliseconds are given for all datasets and for different values of the constraints.Table 2 contains the same data for the LCS measurement. All experiments are carried out on AMD Phenom II X4 945 with 3GB RAM. It is obvious that the introduction of global constraints in both measurements considerably accelerates the process of the distance matrix calculation, which is the direct consequence of a faster similarity measurement.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: Although the Euclidean metric for time series data is simple and very intuitive, it has a known weakness in sensitivity to distortions in the timeline. To overcome this weakness, many elastic metrics (DTW, LCS, ERP, EDR, etc.) are proposed, all based on dynamic programming and with square computational complexity. Global constraints are introduced into dynamic programming algorithms to narrow the search path in the matrix and reduce the computation time. In this paper, we examined the impact of global constraints on two most representative elastic metrics for time series: DTW and LCS. Through an extensive series of experiments, we demonstrated that the use of global constraints can significantly shorten the computation time of these metrics, which is their main weakness. In addition, we showed that the limited metrics are qualitatively different from their unlimited timetables.

metadata.abstractText: A time series consists of a series of values or events obtained over repeated measurements in time. Analysis of time series represents and important tool in many application areas, such as stock market analysis, process and quality control, observation of natural phenomena, medical treatments, etc. A vital component in many types of time-series analysis is the choice of an appropriate distance/similarity measure. Numerous measures have been proposed to date, with the most successful ones based on dynamic programming. Being of quadratic time complexity, however, global constraints are often employed to limit the search space in the matrix during the dynamic programming procedure, in order to speed up computation. Furthermore, it has been reported that such constrained measures can also achieve better accuracy. In this paper, we investigate two representative time-series distance/similarity measures based on dynamic programming, Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) and Longest Common Subsequence (LCS), and the effects of global constraints on them. Through extensive experiments on a large number of time-series data sets, we demonstrate how global constrains can significantly reduce the computation time of DTW and LCS. We also show that, if the constraint parameter is tight enough (less than 10–15% of time-series length), the constrained measure becomes significantly different from its unconstrained counterpart, in the sense of producing qualitatively different 1-nearest neighbor graphs. This observation explains the potential for accuracy gains when using constrained measures, highlighting the need for careful tuning of constraint parameters in order to achieve a good trade-off between speed and accuracy.
